# GuitarLa — E‑commerce (TypeScript + CSS)

A concise, production-ready storefront to browse and buy guitars and accessories. Focused on a clean UI, TypeScript code quality, and responsive CSS styling.

Languages: CSS (49%), TypeScript (48%), JavaScript (1.9%), HTML (1.1%)

## Key features (summary)
- Product catalog with categories and search
- Product detail pages with images and specs
- Shopping cart with quantity updates and totals
- Checkout flow (placeholder for payment integration)
- Responsive layout for mobile and desktop
- TypeScript types for safer code and maintainability

## Quick start
1. Clone the repo
   git clone https://github.com/Kekekingg/GuitarLA-Ts-.git
   cd GuitarLA-Ts-
2. Install dependencies
   npm install
   # or yarn install
3. Create a .env file (see Environment below)
4. Run dev server
   npm run dev
5. Build
   npm run build
6. Start production server
   npm start

(Replace scripts above if your project uses different commands — common names are dev, build, start, test, lint.)

## Environment (minimum)
Create a .env in project root with values required by your app. Typical variables:
- NODE_ENV=development
- PORT=3000
- API_URL=http://localhost:4000/api
- DATABASE_URL=... (if applicable)
- STRIPE_SECRET_KEY=... (if integrating payments)

Do not commit secrets.

## Tech stack (summary)
- TypeScript — application logic and types
- CSS — styling and responsive layout
- (Optional) Framework/library — add actual framework (React, Next.js, Vue, etc.) if used
- (Optional) Backend — Node/Express, Firebase, Supabase, or external API

## Project structure (example)
- src/ — application source (components, pages, styles, api, types)
- public/ — static assets
- tests/ — unit / e2e tests
- package.json — scripts & deps

Adjust to match your repository structure.

## Deployment (summary)
- Host frontend on Vercel, Netlify, or any static host if prebuilt
- For full-stack, use Heroku, Render, DigitalOcean, or Docker
- Set environment variables in host settings (API keys, DB URLs, secrets)

## Payment & data notes
- Use a trusted provider (e.g., Stripe) for payments; keep secret keys server-side
- Store only non-sensitive customer data; follow privacy and PCI compliance best practices

## Contributing (short)
- Fork → branch (feature/...) → commit → push → open PR
- Include tests for new behaviour
- Follow TypeScript types and code style used in the repo

## Tests, linting & formatting
- npm run test (if available)
- npm run lint
- npm run format

Add or adjust commands to match your repository's package.json.
